As for the food, this place has a unique variety of pizzas. There are the more common ones available, like: Pepperoni, Cheese, Comination, etc. However, they also have some pizzas that I had never heard of until I first came here. And the one that comes to mind is one that contains potatoes in it. I have tried it a couple of times nd it's pretty good. 

Also, the staff are pretty friendly nd the environment is peaceful/chill.

I would most def. come back here one day nd it's sad that I am no longer around Polk anymore :[
author: Michael N.

description:
Escape From New York Pizza is often the easy option when I'm the only one in the group hungry after a late night out.  That being said, it's more of a last resort kinda place for me.  I only go here when I'm not patient enough to wait in the much longer line at Pizza Orgasmica, which indisputably serves better pizza than this place.    

The service here is non-existent, the employees either have a blank look on their face like they would rather be anywhere else or are too busy chatting amongst themselves.  This place can't be considered a real late night food joint, since most of the pizza slices they have left by the time 2:00AM rolls around are the leftovers for the day.  They never have any fresh pizzas coming out of the oven even if there is a long line at the door.  More often that not, by the time you get to the front of the long line you are forced you to buy whatever is leftover, essentially helping them clear out their excess inventory for the day.  Half the time the pizza is lukewarm even after they reheat it.  Of all the times I've been there, I've only gotten a slice of pizza with decent toppings once and that was just an average slice.  This place fails miserably as a late night eatery.
author: Wei K.

description:
GREAT pizza!!  We ordered the Hawaiian and the U Say Potato -- and they were both delicious.  

The location is pretty safe ... or safer then the other location I've been to on Haight.

The Hawaiian was great, the only suggestion I'd make is to probably add a bit more pineapple so that I actually got some in every bite, but none-the-less it was still fantastic.  The U Say Potato was very delicious as well.  The pesto did overpower all other tastes on the pizza, but the potato and garlic was very yummy and crunchy!!  It was an interesting slice.

They do accept Visa and Mastercard.  Also, the slices range from about $3-$4.

I will come back here again ... I think about it all the time.  =P
author: Pia V.

description: This is my favorite delivery pizza in the area.  At first I was not a huge fan of how much sauce they used on their pies, but I have learned to simply order with extra cheese and light sauce.  Delivery is always prompt, and I like that they have the system in place that remembers your address by phone number for returning customers.
author: Tony B.

description:
If you aren't drunk, just keep walking.

I'm talking dried out $4 slices that are luke warm at best and reheated like last night's leftovers.  I regret my choice for a quick dinner and would have preferred a stick of beef jerky from Walgreen's across the street instead.

I'll probably be back sometime in the future, but I sure as hell won't remember it.
author: Nick W.

description:
I've never cleaned out a pizza place, but I have to admit, it is a satisfying feeling.  In a generous move, my friend and I offer to walk and get pizza for the group at 2:30 in the morning and bring it back to our other friend's apartment...  We bought 3/4 of a Hawaiian pizza and 3/4 of a cheese pizza.  Hawaiian is my least favorite pizza...but considering the vileness of warm pineapple, the pizza was actually pretty good (kudos to Escape from New York!).  

Pizza was delicious, hot and yummy.  I was impressed that it was open past 2 a.m. - so many places close too early.
author: Wendy L.

description:
So living in North Beach I have tried many a pizza place and I have to say, I love this place.  I have had it many a drunken night strolling down Polk, but where they really shine is home delivery.  I mean we have all been there, no one wants to cook dinner...lets order pizza.  This is the place to order from!  Don't get sucked into North Beach "overpriced and overrated" Pizza because this place wins by far!  

They are fast too! Within 40 minutes you have your pizza!
author: Natalie L.

description:
Yum, this pizza is great at all times of the day and at all meals: 

dinner, late night , lunch leftovers, cold for breakfast 

I like it when I want simple, non-fancy pizza toppings aka not extreme or orgasmica. The toppings are always plentiful and evenly distributed on top of the pizza. There's something so tasty about their sauce, and I love the soft chewy crust, I hate crispy crust. We love getting just pepperoni, mushroom and olive or their combo. A slice of pesto potato is good for late night, after the bars, but otherwise I've found the pesto to be too greasy in a sober state. It is conveniently located on Polk and delivery is usually a standard 45 minutes to an hour.
author: Carolyn K.

description:
The pizza here is pretty decent. I usually get the mushroom. The boyfriend usually gets the peperoni. They toss you slice in the oven for a bit and it gets nice and hot/crispy. Not sure how long the pizzas are sitting under the light for though...

Seating is limited, but not too many people sit and eat here, so there are usually seats available. The service kind of sucks. They always seem annoyed. I get the hipsters-pretending-to-struggle-by-getting-an-easy-job vibe here. That alone usually gets me to keep walking right past it even if I really do want a slice of pizza.
author: Jeanette P.

description: love this place - come here at the end of any night out and there will be a line of people out the door waiting for the perfect way to top off the night. my only complaint is that i love their potato and garlic pizza, but it seems like they're almost always out of it!
author: Amanda L.

description:
I am a huge fan...
Whether I am meandering home after a night at the bars, or having pizza delivered on a night when I don't feel like cooking.... EFNY is the place to get pizza.

'The Gourmet' has feta, sundried tomatoes and artichokes... delicious.

'You Say Potato' is another winner, with pesto, roasted garlic and potatoes.

My favorite build your own: onions, feta, roasted or fresh garlic and artichoke hearts. DELICIOUS.
author: D S.

description: I like them this is where I order from I just wish they did wings and sides you could make a killing.
author: Josh A.

description:
Am I the only one who feels like there should be a ton of Kurt Russell memorabilia everywhere?

Nice, crispy pizza.  Also served up fast - we barely had to wait 2 minutes for our slices.

Very limited selection though.  I mean, when your whole business model is:

1) Make dough
2) Put shit on dough
3) Bake.
4) Profit!

Would it kill ya to put some creativity into step 2?
author: Nathan M.

description: Ah, it's great to have a local pizza spot that sells late-night slices.  My boyfriend comes here every time he visits family and I'm hooked now too.  In Seattle, where we live, there aren't too many slices-joints so the piping hot pep was a nice treat for us.  I'm sure we will be back next time we're in SF!
author: Ashley M.

description:
Solid pizza though we only use for delivery when we're feeling lazy. Best pizza ever? No, but good enough and has easy online ordering. 

The pizza has a medium thickness crust. 

The larger size pizzas tend to get soggy in the middle on delivery, probably because there are more toppings to create excess liquid, so we always just get the smaller size.

We really like their Canadian Bacon.

I'm not a fan of the pesto. 

The potato pizza people rave about is pretty good, even though my husband thought the potato was sausage... sausage-like spices on the potato I guess...

Escape from NY gets 4 stars because we like them enough to come back again and again (over other pizza delivery) even though there isn't really anything special or amazing about the pizza. Fast, consistent, and good value.
author: Emily C.

description:
I am a self proclaimed pizza connoisseur. I grew up in Chicago but appreciate all forms of pizza. It's the perfect medium to convey every possible pallet combination. Escape from New york is a good go to for basic nosh. By no means as bad as the cheaper franchises with processed ingredients. My only true gripe for the quality of the product is the insane prices they charge. 30$ before tip for a medium delivery pizza, seems a little off kilter I;m not ordering buffalo mozzarella and prosciutto!
   Growing up in Chicago there were many small mom and pop places that made far superior of a product and you could get an extra large for the same  price! I'm just sayin.......
author: Brandy R.

description: More like got kicked out of NY. I am a pizza snob, I admit it. I am from NY and lived in the Bronx where I was privileged to eat some of the worlds best pizza. Now I don't expect any pizza in California to be on the same level: but if you are going to use NEW YORK in your store name, please have some respect and come close to making NY pizza. A plain cheese slice should be the best and taste great. This pizza is awful and has zero taste. I guess that's why everyone gets pesto on it.
author: Jesse B.

description: A nice standard pizza pie at a reasonable price.
author: Amanda S.

description: No fuss, no frills, just pure pizza.
author: Martin P.

description:
Oh FXXX!
FXXXin' Hell.
There was a Moron works there blowin' his nose with both hands even though he was usein' a napkin, but  his fingers went into his nose and diggin' shit out.
Oh Yeah, he was diggin' his way to China.
And turned around and said, "Need some help?"
He didn't even care washin' his hands!

He might think that he didn't need to wash his hands because he used napkin.
And he used a spatula to pick a slice pizza up.
But he got a paper plate with the left hand!
HOLYSHIT!
Dude, get serious.
It's a food industry.
Wash your FXXXin' hands after blow your FXXXin' nose!
JESUS!
What kind of management the place has?

I don't want my Sausage Pizza made by his BOOGERS!!!

WhatTheFXXX?

You have no idea what's goin' on inside of  restaurants.

Don't get me wrong, I liked the pizza.
But after the incident?
I don't know I can do that again.
Can you?

I just want the manager must know there is a guy not doing the right thing in the place.

Hey, people are watching.

Btw, 

phillip w. "it adds protein!"

Vanessa W. "yuck!!!!!!!!!!!"

Marian G.  "Ugh!   I can't eat pizza anymore!"

Ken K. "Boogeroni pizza!"

Lolia S. "Boogeroni - gross!"

Steve L. "EEWWWW!  I'll pass on the extra "ingredient". I think my craving for pizza has now been passed."

Katelynn L. " Eww...that's disgusting!!! "

Clyde R. "that's nasty, Nobu, what's up with these people....?"

Don B. " Oh Gawd! "

tinna h. " oh, that is really gross. i never liked that place! :( "
author: Nobu K.

description: I keep trying to find a good pizza in San Francisco .....Dam ? I just tried escape from New york and it will be going in the trash .I paid 24 dollars and I prepaid the tip its not the drivers fault that this pizza was terrible .I was in Detroit recently and had pizza from three different places and they were al pretty dam good but why is it I can not get a good pizza In San Francisco ?????
author: Frank M.

description: This is my favorite pizza place in SF. Great location, price and fast service.
author: Natalie C.

description:
Does this mumu make my ass look fat? Food baby, thy name is Escape from New York.  As a late-night pizza enthusiast, it seems like Escape From New York has taken to setting up shop wherever I happen to be hanging out: the Castro, the Haight, the Mission, next door to my office...and Russian Hill.

So many locations and each one is completely different from the other. I personally like the Castro outlet the best and the financial district location comes in at a close second. This particular branch, conveniently located near a million bars, is not a favorite but they do turn out decent pizza, which becomes delicious pizza after a bottle of champagne and a couple of Stellas. 

Extra star for having loads of options late night, even midweek. Now if only they sold will power...
author: Autumn K.

description:
'Memba that time I said Za has the best pizza in SF?  Well....  Za still has daggone good pizza, but I might have to revise my place order so there's room for a tie at the top, thanks to EFNY's "gourmet" and "you say potato" pies, both of which are *ridiculously* amazingly delicious.  Yumola.  We only order for delivery from this location (we sit and eat at the FiDi space, which is nice enough), so this is just a food review, not ambience or location or any of that nonsense.

We set up an online account and got 20% off our first order (woot!), and now use their "M310" code for saving $3 off an XL pie (what?!  We don't eat it all in one sitting!  Judgey!), which is nice.  Salads are fresh, crisp, varied and tasty, but let's be real:  it's about the pizza.  "Gourmet" is spinach, sun-dried tomatoes aplenty, feta, and artichoke hearts (could be more plentiful), atop a thick tomato sauce (sweet-ish, fyi) and mozz.  Pretty thick crust, but well-cooked so there's definitely a crispness to the underside, and a nice heft to the edge.  Plenty of toppings, usually, and a nice balance of flavors between sweet (cf tomatoes, saucy and sun-dried) and savory (feta, artichoke hearts).  You Say Potato is a lurvely taste sensation, even if it's not the first thing you'd think of in a pizza:  pesto, mozz, thin-sliced red-skinned potatoes, and garlic cloves (which honestly could usually stand to be roasted for longer before being part of the topping, but that's just nit-picking).  Fan-freaking-tastic (note earlier crust comments, which apply here, too:  one of the best things about EFNY pizza is that the crust stands up to the toppings without dominating any bite).

Would it be bad to have pizza twice a week...  every week?!
author: L D.

description: I've tried many pizza places in the area and for some reason, this pizza wasn't as good as I was expecting. The crust was very thin and too crunchy. The sauce was too sweet and the vegetables were small and not completely covered with cheese at all. I wouldn't recommend this place to anybody in San Francisco; however I would have to say that there specials and pricing is not bad for the size of pizza that you get.
author: Brandon R.

description:
Four stars for the mushroom pizza by the slice.  Here's why: they re-heat it for a couple of minutes in their oven; thus restoring the crispy bottom crust!  Love it!  I've never ordered a whole pie, so I can't review that.  I have tried the other toppings, which were fine.  My favorite just happens to be mushroom.  

It's a walk-up location with a few seats.  There's no pretense or nonsense.
author: Stephen F.

description:
Hit this spot up for lunch during work. Definitely one of the best pizza places in the city. Great to know they have a couple of them in the city, however, they do need to venture out into the East Bay. The pizza itself is delicious and very filling. 

- G
author: Gianni A.

description:
I don't know what happened to this place, as far as I can tell they must of restaffed, the guy answering the phone is about 10 times nicer than the jackass that used to work there, but their pizza's are so inconsistent now.

I used to order a pizza from them about twice a month, overjoyed that I found a decent New York style pizza in SF.  Then out of the blue, about 3 months ago I got seriously the WORST pizza I could of imagined.  Seriously, I don't know how you mess up dough, cheese, and sauce, but I guess they started by forgetting to put sauce and cheese on it.  The pie wasn't even cooked, we had to throw out half of it.

After that experience I stopped ordering there for several months, just recently I took the dive again, first pizza was amazing, this last one last night... ugh.  It looked like they didnt' have enough dough to make the pie, so they stretched it as thin as they could, and folded it over itself a few times, and tried to patch it together with little globules of cheese.  The pizza came in like 30 minutes, but somehow it tasted like it was overcooked, yet was already cold when it got to me.   I'm guessing they must of unloaded one of their pies meant for slices on me.

Complete crap though, really dissapointing.  When you spend 20 bucks on a pizza, from a place that ONLY makes pizza's, you REALLY can't mess it up that badly.  Order from this place at your own risk.  You may get a really decent pizza, or you may get some inedible cardboard.

I'm done with these guys now.
author: Tyler D.

description: This location isn't my favorite, downtown makes a better pizza, but that might just be because there's more turnover and fresher pies. Gets its job done for a decent slice after the bars.
author: Emily K.

description:
I don't eat 'slices' in San Francisco

I eat Delfina

I eat Little Star

I don't eat slices.

Nothing pizza related Escaped from New York - all the good pizza is still there. It has not escaped. end of story...
author: Gabe b.

description:
first of all, their menu is a big lie. not only can u get pesto pizza in ny, but you can get f#%$ng amazing pesto pizza in ny. 

what kind of idiot thinks pesto is not available in ny, let alone writes it down on a menu like its a fact? stupid. 

maybe they mean this particular franchise organization corporation doesn't sell their pesto pizza in ny. even more stupid. that just shows that their pizzas don't hold a candle to the competition. 

i mean here's a delicious pesto pizza recipe from the new york times in 1983! 19 m@#$%r f$%@ng 83 

for moth$%r f$%ng sake who do you think invented pesto pizza?

http://events.nytimes.com/recipes/6683/1983/02/16/Pesto-Pizza/recipe.html

anyway, i call this place and tell them i'm coming in to pick up an extra-large box of pizza. they say ok. i show up and say where's my pizza. 

they say what. 

i say where's the pizza. i am picking up an extra large box of pizza. 

they say they haven't started making it yet. 

who said anything about making it? what do you call all these fu$%ng triangular things sitting right in front of me that are covered in toppings? hockey pucks?

i say grab your spatula thing and slide all those pizza slices right under your nose into that extra large box right there and then take my money out of my hands. it's called selling pizza.

i ain't got all day. 

we're finally getting somewhere when the cashier stalls. the exchange of funds takes mot$%#r f$45ng FOREVER as fingers get counted. fingers? i'll show you fingers. 

ok, now i know you're just trying to kill me. i'm going to be 83 by the time i get my change from fingers over here. it's subtraction for fu$%$#ks sake not trigonometry

i get it. they had to escape from ny. anyone who operated a pizza joint like this in ny would be done. out of business in a week. i don't even care if the pope himself blesses this pizza. it's over. done. nada. nothing. forget it.
author: Mulberry S.

description:
Fair warning.  I lived in New York for 4 years.  I happened to love New York style pizza and quite frankly anybody who doesn't like New York style pizza is a (as Allen from The Hangover might say) re-tard.  Either that or they like Chicago style pizza which I guess is good especially if I'm trying to gain say...... a 1000 pounds.  

Anyways.  Its pizza.  Its good when your drunk and stumbling home from the bars.  I wouldn't order this for dinner or any other occasion because its not worth eating when your sober.
author: Peter C.

description:
I eat slices.

I've never been to NYC so I'm off the hook in that regard, but thank goodness for this place on Polk St.
author: L C.

description:
I went here last night and have been thinking about that piece of pizza since. I got the U Say Potato pizza. Potato, pesto, and giant cloves of garlic. Once of the most delicious things I've ever eaten. YUM! 

The crust is thin and crunchy, the slices are HUGE, and omg the toppings are to die for. I can't wait to go back!
author: Victoria A.

description:
I'm more of a Chicago style pizza kind of girl.. I like my crust thick and doughy. But this pizza was still very tasty! I had the potato pesto and garlic slice and it was delicious. Super garlicky though, so make sure you have gum after. 

They're open late too! Like super late!
author: Joy A.

description:
Too bad the pizza here is so good because I might have to come back. The stoned-out-of-their-minds idiots that work here nearly ruined this place for me.

When a customer calls in an order for a pizza and a salad then comes all the way to their restaurant and gets told "Uhh yeah dude we're outta salad."  
"I'm sorry what are you talking about, we just put in an order for a salad."  
"Uhh yeah I dunno we like don't have any lettuce or something."  

Then 3 stoned, dirty, and obnoxious guys walk back in from smoking and the guy goes "why are you taking orders for salads?"   
... 
"I dunno dude we're like out of salad."

PULL IT TOGETHER. Who taught you work ethic?
author: Abbie B.

description:
What's not to like about this spot?  Great thin crust pizza... the best of the standard fare pizzeria kind, IMHO.  

It's got that nice crunch on the underside and just enough chew on the lip.  Toppings taste fresh and the cheese is not too oily.  

It's a very great "everyday" kind of pizza.  But certainly not a destination.
author: Calvin N.

description: Glad to find a consistent slice of pizza that I have eaten at other S.F. Escape From NY spots. The seating is a bit tight.
author: Infodiva B.

description:
I don't claim to know anything about New York style pizza. But I do claim to know what tastes good. And this pizza tastes good. 

If we need an easy dinner for a group before a big night out, we order a large Potato Pesto pizza. It is always made fresh and has huge delicious garlic cloves sprinkled on top. 

After a big night, we'll often stop in for a quick slice. Sometimes the line is long, and I usually wish there were more seating, but for the price and the taste (and the time of night), I just don't mind.

We are regulars! Good, easy, freshly baked pizza and nice staff.
author: Lauren M.

description:
Pretty yummy, especially after a night of going out, then its phenomenal and hits the spot.  Although the line may be a bit long, have no fear, it moves really fast.  

I really enjoyed the Andy Warhol.  A supper yummy large slice with lots and lots of toppings.  No skimping here.  This pizza is good, not the best but if you are near and craving pizza, then this is the place.
author: Cara D.

description:
a message to my fellow lactards!

i got the fake cheese thing that is suposed to be non-dairy and non-soy which also turns out to be non-eatable. DO NOT GET THE FAKE CHEESE. i cant make it through my pizza. if i got it without cheese I am pretty sure it would be good. my girlfriend was happy with hers, she says 4/5.
author: Dico B.

description:
When I'm looking for late-night pizza I want something so sinfully indulgent that I can only convince myself to eat it if I am hammered.

The crust on this pie is thin with the right consistency, the price is cheap enough, but the toppings and ingredients are lacking.  The Pesto was relatively bland; very little pesto flavor and no real ooey gooeyness.  Maybe I've been spoiled by Artichokes in NY but when I think of late night pizza I want something that's so calorie-laden I feel bad about it the next morning.
author: Hamilton W.

description: Pizza is pretty good and big here but talk about F'n ATTITUDE. These guys actually think they're from NY. I'm a New Yorker and never received this type of treatment. The server was actually nice but the female cashier did not want to be there.  I get it, it's not a 5 star restaurant, they only serve pizza. I asked for two slices of pizza and they said it was fresh so figured didn't need to heat it up. Come out take a bite of both slices and find out it's really really cold. I go back and ask to be heated and they say, they can't bc they were eaten.  They finally say they will but will need to cut the bitten part off. I get my pizza back and 3/4 of it were taken off. I only took one bite of each, did they really have to cut off 3/4 of it. I'm furious and request new slices and the cashier girl is asking if I'd like my money back. They gave me one slice and refunded the other. As I was leaving the workers made me feel like piece of Shi!, waving goodbye, have a nice day in the most condescending way in front of all their customers. Would I ever go back, HELL NO. Should you give it a try? Sure go and find out what it feels like to be treated by As$hole servers and cashiers.
author: Steve N.

description:
This will absolutely do! It is the best neighborhood pizza joint I have had since my tenure at UCLA- Westwood has 2+ pizza joints, 1 of which is open past last call. 

I had pepperoni and cheese- the cheese was better and unfortunately I burned the roof of my mouth on it. 

I will very likely be back and be satisfied. 4 would require ranch dressing which i heart with pizza!
author: Jess V.

description: My grandmother was raving about this place! So we decided to give it a try after a road trip back from Napa. We ordered pepperoni and pesto. The pesto was pretty good, but kinda of try. I liked pepperoni more though! I had to disagree with most of the people here regarding their service. Their service was excellent! The guy even said "xie xie" (thanks) to us on our way out!. I think the pizza would taste better if you ordered a whole pizza because it would be fresher.
author: Amy Y.

description: No complaints here. The staff here is always really friendly and they serve a great product. The pizza here seems remarkably similar to Pizza Orgasmica and I can't shake the feeling the PO has a slight edge, but it really depends on which one is closer for me. Like PO it also has the benefit of its late night hours but doesn't suffer from the longer lines and wait times of its competitor.
author: Taylor C.

description: Why pretend to be something you're not? "Escape from New York" don't expect to walk in here and hear any music aside from east coast rap with staff who look the part as well. Honestly, it makes for a nice change given all the artisan/hipster vibes most places in the city have. I can appreciate a pizza place that's rough around the edges. The pizza is par and they have a very popular potato pizza which my gf loves. Prices aren't cheap but are in line with the area. If I'm having a pizza craving and want to grab a few slices to-go, this is my joint.
author: Reed P.

description:
This is how pizza should be done!!! 

After a long night, the staff at Rouge Nightclub, which is right next door, gather around a big pie, courtesy of Escape From New York, and laugh the night away. An authentic New York style pizza joint in the city by the bay.

New Yorkers would be proud!!

I personally recommend their Chicken, Tomato and Pesto Pizza!!
GREEN LIGHT STATUS!!!!
author: Brent F.

description:
Gimme gimme more, gimme more, gimmmmmm mooorrreeeeeee!!!!!

Ok Brit Brit, I love this pizza pie! For dinner or late night, Im humming happy tunes while I stand in line salivating for the perfect slice of this magical pizza. Whats so magical? Oh the size itself is, and its quite magical you can get it all for $3!!! I gravitate towards the Hawain or the Pesto, usually a slice of both. Thanks to the lovely Lil Thur I was introduced to this place a year ago. Once an Orgasmica addict, this place takes the lead in my vote for order by the slice pizza. 

It looses half a star cause its not in my hood, another half cause when you order the actual pie itself its a little below the quality of individual slices.
author: Heather S.

description: Love the U You Say Potato.  I've had the mushroom one as well... it's good but the potato one is the winner winner potato dinner.  Some other places make this potato pesto combo, but not all of them will sell it by the slice.
author: Erika C.

description: Great spot for a slice of pizza after a drunken evening, in the morning... (errrr, afternoon?) to shake off a hangover or simply when you're craving a big, cheesy, greasy, slice! I love this place! It's tiny on the inside so don't plan on sitting around, but other than that this place is A+ in my book.
author: Laila P.

description:
I feel the need. The need for speed. And sometimes, fast delivery after day drinking will do just the trick. 

After a few hours of watching the air show and the Blue Angels, my friends and I craved sustenance. Tossing back lots of champagne and Pacificos is grueling work, and don't you forget it.  So while we girls held down our jobs of looking good and getting crunk on the roof, the boys took it on to get us some pizza.

Guy #1: Hey everybody, situation is under control. Escape from NY will be here in thirty.

Guy #2: Awesome! What kind did you get?

Guy #1: Pepperoni and sausage. In this apartment, we don't eat vegetables. It's delicious.

Guy #2: Dude. Get the pesto potato pizza. I'm not even kidding. I fucking hate vegetarians and I love that pizza. It's bomb.

Since the boys wanted to avoid an argument (or maybe because unlike girls, there's no need to get catty over pizza) we opted to get both the potato pesto and the pepperoni sausage. 

And hot damn, those boys can be my wingmen any time because they did quite alright by this girl. The pepperoni sausage was good, and the pesto potato was phenomenal. The only downside were the giant cloves of garlic on top, scaring any potentials away for the evening. But that's fine, because I wound up in an Oregon football bar with a bunch of 40 year old men, not exactly what you would call a target rich environment.

So for all you gentlemen out there, and because I can't help but squeeze another stolen line in: Take me to Escape from NY or lose me forever!
author: Devon S.

description:
You ever have one of those nights when you leave the house to meet up with someone for a quick cup of coffee with the full intention of being home in half an hour to eat dinner?  Then it's suddenly 10:30pm and you have a nice buzz going because you forgot you left the house without eating?  

If this happens to you and you happen to be on Polk Street, a slice of pepperoni from Escape From New York will definitely hit the spot. I don't remember much about the slice other than it being big and greasy...actually, just what I needed at the time.
author: phil h.

description:
This pizza is so good and so close to NY pizza that I almost thought I was back in NYC. As I sat there, eating my plain slice drowned with garlic powder, I stared out the window imagining that I was in fact back in New York. 

If it weren't for all the fucking hippies walking by and the fucking prius driving by or all the people wearing shorts with Northface Sweaters, I could have pretended for a little while longer. 

Stupid prius. 
Stupid hippies. 
Stupid people wearing shorts with NorthFace sweaters.
author: Jen D.

description:
From what I remember it was good, but what I remember most about it was the garlic it left in my system days later... I'm finally garlic free. And will most likely avoid potent garlic friendly pizzas the rest of my life. It left me with a 3 day memory of that night. Scary! 

Good thing my only guilty pleasure was a slice of pizza at 1:00AM!

PS my boyfriend still loves me.
author: Dee C.

description:
Liked it.
Didn't *love* it.

Maybe it was my fault.  Like Joshua S, I try to 
experience a new slice shop by ordering a 
basic cheese slice right off.

Well, the pepperoni had just come out of the 
oven so I though, yeee ha!  I'll take that one!  I 
really had high hopes of finding a nice alternative 
to hiking UPHILL to get to Za but:

* Crust was a little thicker than I consider to be
   "East Coast Style"
* Sauce was a little too tangy
* Had to hold the slice vertically to let the bright 
   orange oil puddle up on my paper plate
* Cheese coverage was good - with a nice border
   to use as a handle.

I am very sure that I will give EFNY another chance because 
in the long run, it's still PIZZA and pizza-by-the-slice is primo!
author: K-leen F.

description: Love this place. Friendly service and great pizza by the slice. They also are patient with my sometimes unruly children.
author: Susie T.

description:
Okay, I just wrote a less than favorable review on one of the more popular Chicago style pizza places in SF, supposedly the best Chicago style pizza in SF.  That was such a disappointment that I decided to do what any true pizza lover would do...real New York style pizza!

I have never had a whole pizza here (yet!), but get slices at this location often.  In my opinion, this is the closest thing to genuine, real, authentic NY style pizza I've ever had outside of NYC.  I still remember it vividly since I was in NY twice last year.  I hit Carnegie Deli again too (oh my gawd, pastrami on rye, best in the world, orgasm of the mouth!), but that's a story for another day. 

Escape from NY Pizza on Polk St is virtually identical to the many (and I do mean many, all different owners too) Ray's Pizza places that I've frequented while in Manhattan.  Yes, it's greasy...dripping off the pizza and you have to fold it in half to enjoy it, but d#mn that's authentic!

The slices are pretty big too.  Some people have told me that they like Extreme Pizza.  I'll never know if they're any good since I went only once years ago when Extreme first opened.  They had a sign out front that said Extreme BIG slices!  I had a slice and it was the most pathetic little triangle I had ever seen.  I was like what...'Extreme'ly small?  They burned me once and I never went back.  Anyway, back to Escape:

There are many other pizza places that I love in SF (Pasquales on Irving, Gaspare's, Bella, Giorgio's, Tommaso's, etc), each of them special in their own way, but when I want real NY pizza, there is only one place I go and this is it, Escape from NY.  Bonus points for staying open late and being on the site of the old Pizza My Heart.  Those were some good times back in the Johnny Love days.
author: Roy N.

description:
A great spot to have a slice after enjoying the bars on Polk.  I'm pretty familiar with their location on Haight St. as the bars in upper Haight are my preferred stomping grounds.  But Escape from NY is just as good here!  My personal favorite is a vegetarian pizza that has artichoke hearts and feta cheese, mainly because of the two aforementioned toppings.

To pickup a slice after drinking is a great inexpensive snack that satisfies and tastes great.  They also have a self serve water dispenser, in case you need to re-hydrate quickly.

If you eat here outside late on a Saturday night, be prepared to inhale some smoke from the smokers outside the neighboring club.  On the bright side, you'll get to enjoy the eye candy of skanky looking girls.  Que Bueno!
author: Eric L.

description: Offered to buy a homeless a slice of pizza and the worker said that the "homeless lady does not want it" this is without asking her or offering her and refused the let me pay for the poor homeless lady....  let me just clear this for the fellow Yelpers, I OFFERED TO PAY FOR THE DAMN SLICE. This is not how things work in SF. Not to mention the food sucks.
author: Jasmine L.

description: It does the trick. Not the best and not the worst. I like the fact that it's thin and the crust is very fluffy. Good for its price. Their cesar salad is actually pretty darn good. Close to home. Quick in and out. Cheap.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
I've been in San Fran for 4 days and have eaten lunch here twice. The slices are big and full of flavor. I had the Hawaiian on day one and the Mushroom on day two only because they didn't have the Hawaiian sitting out on day two. Disappointing but the Mushroom didn't let me down. The slices aren't oversauced and seriously make me consider going back there for dinner and even breakfast if they were open that early.

The people that work there are really nice and if you're lucky enough for one of the two tables outside to be free as well as it be a nice enough day to sit outside, then you can actually have a somewhat pleasant pizza lunch.
author: Danny K.

description: We ordered an extra cheese and Peperoni pizza.  It was ready in about 20 minutes.  the final price was $21.  The shop was close to our hotel so we just went to pick it up.  They could have delivered but we where walking up around Polk St. already.  The pizza was delicious and the Peperoni had a spiciness to it.  I usually put Pepper flakes on my pizza but the spiciness of the Peperoni was just enough.  The crust was just right a little softer and it might have been to soft more liking.  You will get a great pizza by choosing Escape.
author: Carlos U.

description: escape doesn't have the greatest of pizzas but then again i'm not a huge pizza fan. the only reason why i'm giving this place 4 stars is because they always seems to be open when everything else is closed, the staff is hilarious is you catch them when its slow and there always seems to be at least one slice of something that is tasty.
author: Cescilia A.

description:
This pizza is mediocre at best. I remember it being better after an evening out. I tried it again last week at the beginning of the evening and my piece was terribly overcooked and underseasoned. Yawn.

For the best pizza in the city, head to Golden Boy and pass on Escape from New York.
author: Jessica C.

description:
We had 2 1/2 meals between 5 girls from 2 of these pizzas delivered to my friend's place.  One for dinner, one for 4th meal at 2 AM, and one for the next morning.  That's a fabulous deal!  

I loved the cheese pizza...yes, I am that boring, but it was perfect.  Just enough cheese, good sauce, good crust.  Great delivery pizza.  The pizza is huge too, definitely a good deal for pretty decent pizza.
author: Elizabeth W.

description:
I really dig this place.  Not only because I, myself, recently escaped from New York, but because I wish I could have taken the pizza with me on my way West.  

It's ~$2 and up for a slice, and the delivery is unbeatable -- the pie was much hotter, much fresher, and much more delicately savory than the ones I normally get from Mozz de Buff (toppings are canned, only order the cheese), Pizza Orgasmica (too heavily loaded; almost wet), and Amici's (greasy, but excellent sausage).  

The pesto pie, in particular, kills.  Minus one star for being cash only.
author: Ann M.

description:
Three stars for the pizza and an extra star for the friendly customer service.  

The place is tiny and is really a pizza-to-go / pizza-by-the-slice shop.  Don't come here with a handful of friends and a fistful of dollars because there's only one tiny counter with about for stools.  They have two or three small, steel tables just outside too.

Assuming you like thin crust pizza, there is neither anything wonderfully outstanding nor anything horribly wrong with it.  With that said, here are some pies that are praiseworthy, such as the pesto & roasted garlic and the odd, but tasty, meatball and cheddar cheese.  The pepperoni is above average as well.  

If you are ordering a slice, sometimes they don't leave it in the oven long enough, so just ask them to leave it in for a few extra secs.  They're nice, they'll do it for you.
author: Tom Y.

description:
Good pizza, good people.

The crust is much better than the previous Nick's Sicilian style which was here prior to EFNY.
author: shaun l.

description: Tasty Pepperoni and the meat combo. Fast service, shotty to-go wrapping, bad rap music... But it's pizza... It's hard to go wrong with pizza. Hard.
author: Jodie B.

description: I enjoyed the service here, which is unexpected for this type of restaurant. I've had the Hawaiian pizza (good) and the potato pesto pizza, which was highly recommended but too much potato (and I usually love potato). A solid meal for under $6.
author: Zelda Z.

description: After visiting this spot more times than I'd like to admit to, bumping this back down a few notches.  The pizza just never really impresses here, I don't know if I always get the stale pies or what.  There are way too many great pizza places in SF compared to the ol' escape.  It is really awesome eating a slice here late night and watching the clientele stumble out of Rouge, that is for sure.
author: William B.

description: I'm not huge on pizza so a pizza place has to be pretty amazing to get my vote... Escape from New York on Polk doesn't really do it for me though... I've had it a couple times and even late night when I'm really needing some greasy carbs, it's not that satisfying in my opinion. I find it a little bland and pretty ordinary. One positive for Escape is that the line usually moves fast and the pizza is usually out of the oven, hot, and ready to go... I think my funniest experience at Escape was ending up covered in parmesan cheese and spicy pepper because I loaded so much onto my pizza to make it more interesting...
author: Meghan P.

description: It's only fitting that I write a review for Escape From NY after writing one for Buster's -- this is the other drunk munchy place within walking distance from my apartment. Also a good go for a quick slice BEFORE hitting Polk street. Whiskey on an empty stomach leads to nothing good, my friends.
author: Adam D.

description:
A wise man once said "The 'You Say Potato' pizza knocks my balls off."
                                                   
I don't think I can say it any better than my husband, but I do think this place is pretty good. I have mainly eaten the slices on numerous drunken nights out. They serve a 3 star slice of pizza; the amount of drinks I have consumed always makes it seem more like a 5 star experience. On a sober outing, they are not as great. 
I have heard great things about the pizza ordered fresh so that may be a better option if you've got the time.
author: Lilly O.

description:
It's been awhile since I've been to New York, but I still remember the pizza. You could get a slice almost anywhere. Always a slice of cheese ("plain") folded lengthwise, grease dripping on the paper plate. Never too cheesy, never too saucy, crust thin, not crunchy. Used to wash it all down with a Coke with ice. Good memories.

Well, Escape from New York Pizza will definitely not be making memories the same way all the Ray's did. It's a nice tribute to NYC pizza, but it doesn't really live up to the real stuff.

We've been here twice now together in the last month. Once was very late at night a few weeks back. I thought it was great to have a bite that was decent so late at night without having to sit down at a table and order from a server. Tonight was a complete accident. Nick's Crispy Tacos was closed (shouldn't places be open just five minutes passed their posted times for people who are stuck in traffic?).

The food is OK. The cashier was appropriately apathetic. The counter was dirty thanks to the wonderful patrons who thinks that mom works there. It was more of a utility meal than anything. So why three stars? Well, they were playing great music. That always gets to me.

So if you're looking for New York pizza, go to Oakland and jet to New York on JetBlue. If you're looking for something late at night to fill your tummy, Escape from New York could serve you well.
author: Dave B.

description:
When most eateries on Polk are closed, Escape from New York is open. They've got decent pizza and prices. Other than that, nothing really redeeming, but nothing really wrong with it either. 

Last time I was there a fight broke out inside the teeny tiny parlor. What a bunch of monkeys! The workers were super quick to help break it up and boot them out. Glad to see them take care of business so quickly!
author: Kelly C.

description:
We order deliveries from here from time to time, which are always quick and friendly.

Most importantly, their "You Say Potato" pizza (roasted & sliced potatoes and roasted garlic cloves over pesto) is truly a thing of delicious beauty.
author: Sharand N.

description: The Buffalo wings were cold, the pizza was cold, they forgot to deliver the ranch dressing for the wings, and the croutons for the salad (despite my asking him to repeat my order). When I called to say what was wrong with my order, I was put on hold for several minutes. When the guy got back on the phone, he said, "we'll take off the ranch [which was included in the price of the wings], and try to deliver it right next time." He got off the phone before I could tell him there won't be a next time.
author: Tyler W.

description: It is always a solid choice when I do not know what kind of pizza I want.  It was a toss up between Za Gourmet and here.  I got Za last time so I figured I would go with Escape this time.  I got an XL pepperoni pizza.  Came out to 25 bucks including tip after I used the 3 buck off coupon.  The pizza came in about 35 min which was fast, and they gave me crushed red peppers and parmesan cheese, liked as i asked for, I hate when they leave them out so that was a plus.  The pizza isnt anything special but its always consistent which is fine by me when I cant figure out what I want for dinner.  I will keep coming back.
author: Mark M.

description:
Such an improvement over that hot mess of a "pizza" place, Nick's Pizzeria. i totally imagine the EFNY dudes coming in and being like look your pizza sucks! it is hard and cold! please let us take you over and sicilian hits will not be placed on the heads of nick's family thank you!

Thank YOU, Escape from New York!
author: Shannon V.

description:
Lord, i have been looking for a good pizza place! Last place that was here i got food poisoning from. So it's nice to see a new place. I got the 
Potatoes & Roasted Garlic Cloves with pesto. I was a cynnic too but it was delicious! Granted it was late night after drinking and my first drop of food since 11am...but i would go back in a heartbeat. Thank god my friend lives nearby!
author: Kai T.

description: SF has a severe deficit of "walking around pizza" -- that is, pizza that is best consumed while avoiding eye contact with other pedestrians on a crowded sidewalk.  There are probably better sit down places (Little Star, etc.), but if you're on your way from point A to point B, this is the ideal companion slice for the journey.  Minus one star because it could be cheaper.
author: BringMy C.

description: Good my style pizza, bit pricy but have never had a bad piece and they haven't messed up an order
author: Matthew M.

description: Escape from New York Pizza has saved me so many times when I was in need of  snack while on the go. Their prices seemed to have gone up a little or my mind is forgetful. I'm a sucker for the potato and garlic pizza. It's really greasy and will make your breath smell like death, yet it's really comforting. The crust is pretty good too, soft but crispy.
author: Michael H.

description: I very much enjoyed my slice of pepperoni.  A fair price and they took my $100 bill with no guff.  A perfect food to accompany your sports bar outing down the street.
author: Marc S.

description: Never had real New York pizza, but my husband has and he loved this pizza. He said it was the best pizza he had since he was in NY and I agree, it was delicious. They delivered before the estimated time and the pie was hot. Loved it, would eat here again.
author: Razzle D.

description: Dissapointed, the pizza was def not NY style, it was Dominos style. Not only did they forget the ranch that I ordered and paid for but there was no parmesean or red peppers. The crust was less than special, it was thick and gooey which I hate and the crust is what seperates NY pizza from other pizzas. Once I started eating it I discovered pepporoni on my pizza and I'm a stict vegetarian so I had to throw the whole thing away.
author: sarah m.

description: Not the best pizza I had, but if your on the go and in a hurry it's a good option.
author: Maria C.

description:
Don't know how to rate this pizza bc I am so picky... 

My favorite type of pizza is a fresh pure tomato sauce, quality mozz that's not salty, and thin crispy crust. Escape's pizza is solid. Not a destination but if I'm nearby, I'd grab a piece.

Price is fine, late hours are great.
author: Marina N.

description:
I only go here for late-night eats. (When Za is closed.)

I always feel ill after eating it. 

The mushroom is good, but the pepperoni is baaaad. 

And the cheese coagulates. 

Sometimes they run out late at night - that sucks.
author: Erin M.

description: "Thinner crust" pizza is more accurate than "thin crust" pizza. Too much dough for me. Ordering online is great and the delivery was fast, so you get an extra star for that. But sadly, the pizza itself is disappointing, it probably works as a last resort but probably not something I will order again.
author: Maggie X.

description:
Dear Lactose Intolerance,

I am sorry for indulging in Escape from NY Pizza so much.  I know it hurts you, but alas!  The pizza is so delicious, and the toppings so delightful... I cannot deny myself the indulgence.

Perhaps if  their service was not so great... perhaps if they were not so easily accessible throughout SF... maybe THEN would I be able to resist the call of the oozing fresh cheese.... 

yuuummmmm....
author: Carrie B.

description:
Day 163 of the search for a good slice of New York-style pizza in SF. This isn't it.

First slice: plain cheese. On the doughy side with a too-crisp crust (probably because it was reheated in an industrial-size toaster oven). Pleasantly greasy, though the sauce is a bit too sweet and tangy.

Second slice: pepperoni, not reheated (in fact slightly undercooked). Tons of pepperoni coverage, but way too greasy.

A step up from Nicky's Crust-o-rama but nothing to write home about. The search continues...

(Edited 2 hours later) aw man, whoever said that they felt sick after eating here wasn't kidding... everything is *not* coming up Milhouse this evening.
author: Milhouse V.

description:
WHY!!!!??? Why do they still employ the stoner who takes the orders?? He gets my order wrong EVERY time!! 
Ok, so the pizza is good, but I get salad, and he can't remember any order after 10 seconds, he has the memory of a goldfish.
This is the first time I have felt pissed off enough to write a review.
author: Paul E.

description:
After a marathon Friday night of drinking, we stumbled over to Nick's Crispy only to find that it was closed. Crestfallen.

Next best thing or at least next door? Pizza! I'm not one to discriminate - bring it on. The line was out the door, but moved really quickly. I picked out some pesto potato slice. 

OMG. Seriously. I don't know if it was my inebriated state, but this was a little slice of heaven in my mouth. Danger danger. Now I have somewhere to hit on my way home from the Polk bars. My tastebuds are thanking me, but my hips aren't.
author: Jenny S.

description:
Ever since I moved out of the lower haight, I've missed my weekly trips up to the upper haight for pizza.  Finding out that Escape From New York is opening up a Russian Hill outpost has been the best news this new york escapee has heard in 2007 (and 2007 has been pretty good so far).

Bring on the veggie combo!
author: james s.

description:
The Potato garlic topping is one reason I visit this place and the second is its proximity to sports bar along Polk street. Their thin crust is good but it would be awesome if they could reduce the grease and go easy with the garlic toppings. 

That said, it doesn't really matter when I am drunk and super hungry. ;)
author: Rahul P.

description:
I would eat, the potatoe one, then veggie, then pepperoni, then Ceasar salad and then come back in coupla hours to get 1 more potatoe slice.
M M M !
author: Cat of a Donut J.

description: Excellent pizza! I had a slice of Hawaiian and my parents each had a slice of cheese. Growing up in NJ, I got accustomed to a certain style of pizza, and I felt right at home eating here. The true indicator was that my dad wanted a second piece. He's a very picky eater so for him to want more really says something. I can't wait to go back and try some of the other varieties they had. I almost failed to mention that it's reasonably priced. Slices are pretty big and one would probably satisfy most people's lunch appetite.
author: Jason M.

description:
$3.65 for a slice of cold pizza.

That makes baby Jesus cry.
author: John E.

description:
Just after culinary school I lived in Italy, and did a culinary apprenticeship there. Needless to say, as an unpaid apprentice, I had very few lire to spend on meals out, and the few I did eat out were at pizzerias. Well, my pie-eating compatriots, consider yourselves lucky to have Polk Street's Escape to New York's excellent slices so close at hand. The crust on Escape's pies rivals that of the Italian pies that sustained me as a hungry apprentice - nice and thin, with a slightly elastic chew and a bubbled, pillowy edge. The toppings are good quality - always fresh and flavorful. The sauce is richly tomato-y and the seasonings well balanced. Even the mozzarella, usually  flavorless, greasy goo in most American pizzerias, has a mild creamy flavor and minimal grease. The slices are big and the toppings generous - one usually does the trick for a dinner on the run.

The staff couldn't be nicer - for all the complaints I read below, I wonder if any of those with gripes made the effort to be cordial to the staff. I've eaten there dozens of times and all of them are very pleasant and friendly.
author: Shell H.

description: I have had amazing pizza and not-so-amazing pizza here.  its still pretty good, but not the SF Pizza savior I once thought it was.
author: Kacy L.

description: I liked their Potato garlic pesto pizza, very unique and tasty
author: Jack A.

description: My GO-TO place for pizza on weekdays/weekends. Decent priced pizza ~ 3.50-4 bucks a slice. Can't go wrong with the Potato/Garlic or the Spinach/Artichoke slices.
author: Landon Y.

description:
This pizza is pretty damn good and even better at 2 am.  There's usually never a line and I'm able to quiet the damn pizza cravings that I tend to get every, oh, two days or so.  This is always a better bet than the crowded Marina pizza places (Orgasmica....) and the staff is so incredibly nice!  The salads are a little touch and go, but over all, great pizzas by the slice.  

It's not on the same 4-star level as Pizzeria Delfina or Za, but it's still a great slice.

Bravo for staying open later now!
author: Kathleen B.

description:
Mediocre pizza, and don't expect great delivery service. I called for delivery, and they said it would be 40 minutes. I called back over an hour later and was informed that they "tried to call" -- which was a lie. They had two numbers, my cell phone and the buzzer at the door (which rings another cell phone).

Go elsewhere for delivery!
author: L D.

description:
The pizza tastes fresh, the price is right in an otherwise expensive neighborhood,  and they consistently stay open late, so give 'em three stars out of the gate.

The pizza itself, however, keeps it from getting another star. They put out the same four or five types of pie every night. They skimp on the toppings as much as any pizza parlor I've ever seen. I mean, seriously, I ordered a "meat special" slice and you could count the morsels ot beef or sausage on one hand. And these were not "chucks" - they were "morsels." The Hawaiian had maybe four or five little pieces of pineapple and three small circles of ham. It's tasty, but it's pathetically under-topped. Only the "Potesto," with potato slices and garlic, had enough ingredients sufficient to cover the crust and/or sauce.

If you have the time, and it's earlier, you're much better off going up to the sister location - Za Pizza on Hyde Street, whose owners also have a stake in this place.
author: Nitram N.

description:
For those of you who have put down vegetarian fare when it comes to pizza, disregard no more....U Say Potato will change your religion.  This tiny store offers very little seating, but lots of tasty choices....

Years ago, my office brought in this pizza pie that I swore no one's going to touch...it's got potatoes on it for pete's sake...why swarm there when there's tons of feta/spinach and garlic chicken steaming right there...but one bite, had my group fighting tooth and nail for every slice....I think I found the pie of years yore.

The caramelized garlic chunks on the pie really brings out the savory pesto sauce and the cheese was hot and piping.

For $3.65...get yourself a slice and enjoy.
author: Pauline L.

description:
Polk Street NEEDS pizza, like...

peanut butter needs jelly,
warm chocolate chip cookies need milk,
lohan needs her water bottle,
I need beer.

I'm glad Escape and Za teamed up to save all of us on Polk Street from our delirious "wondering in the desert without water" existence that was the few months our otherwise lovely hood endured without pizza by the slice.

From the doughy days of That's Amore to the tragically ambitious drama of Nicky's, our tribulations have finally been rewarded with Escape.  We are all better people for the trials, but I would not wish to experience the lost years (months) again.

God save the king.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Great location, huge slices, tasty pizza...

Some days, it's this place that keeps me alive.  Sometimes, I don't have the time to cook or go to a restaurant... sometimes I just need a quick bite to fill me up.  I automatically run to Escape from NY.  I love this place.  Pizza's always good, staff is always friendly, and the convenience can't be beat (since I live a couple of blocks away).
author: Elena I.

description:
During one of my recent visits to the area,  a group of buddies and I went bar hopping for while and when the old stomach started rumbling and the drinks got expensive, we picked up some fresh alcohol supplies and then headed back.  After we arrived, everyone decided they were starving but we didn't want to go back out so it was "let's order pizza!" So I whipped out Yelp and searched for Pizza in the area and Escape from NY Pizza sorted to the top.  We took a chance on their pizza because several of the natives said they had never eaten there even after living in the area for many years.  

The order arrived well before they promised and the delivery guy was really nice as he knew he was dealing with some folks who were starving but had been drinking all afternoon.  Once we tore into the pizza, I knew we had selected a good place.  The crust as not super thick  but it was not crispy either.  The toppings were generous but nothing fancy - we kept it simple and had more than enough pizza for leftovers. 

Overall, the pizza, delivery and price was much better than I ever expected.
author: G M.

description: Great veggie slices with artichoke hearts.
author: kim k.

description:
UGH. I am so lazy and this place is 2 blocks from my apt. The service is always friendly. Tasty pesto pizza- especially if you pile on the spicy pepper flakes. 

For the pesto or any slice, respectably, I also like to add my personal flavor enhancement by pouring 3 or 4 heaping spoonfuls of Parmesan cheese on top, then microwaving till melted....

What? Don't judge me.
author: Laura D.

description: yuck this place sucks .overpriced too and nothing like pizza in ny
author: oliver g.

description: I have gone to this place over 25 times i would say.  I think its great.  Always easy in and out. And eating there is fine too. The pizza seems to be real NY style which is where i am from.  Good place, go there.
author: Patrick V.

description:
After a super long day we decided to forego cooking, going out and opted on having a pizza delivered, big mistake! I noticed that Escape took over the old pizza spot next to Nick's and decided to try it out.

We ordered a large with numerous toppings and waited for 45 minutes. After paying the guy $32 + tip we tried it out.  The pizza was lukewarm at best, the crust was undercooked (think gummy) and the sauce had zero flavor. They did include quite a few toppings and made it within their allotted time hence the two stars. Seriously I think much better pizza's are available in the frozen food isle.  Maybe it was an off night or something but I won't be testing that theory out anytime soon.
author: Kacey H.

description:
Did I miss something?  When did pizza prices skyrocket to $3.90 for a reheated slice of boring potato pesto?  Still, this was a needed snack after a Yelp party and it did the trick.

Also, the dudes who work here were playing some good music.  That is all.
author: Cory G.

description:
Serves a purpose I guess, i.e. drunk and hungry.

I think they need to check themselves personally. Have you ever gotten a soda from here before? It tastes like turd covered in burnt hair, and I think its the water. They should drink the water and then figure it out, cuz the water goes in the pizza and I think thats what gives it it's funky ass taste. 

That being said, if hungry/bored/drunk/desperate try the pesto slice, its the only truly respectable pie they serve. Greasy, but respectable.
author: Jeff G.

description: Great place to get a large slice of pizza for a little over $3, that potato pesto and pepperoni is great.
author: A Z.

description:
A quick thin slice, 
Served up hot to curb the urge, 
Lacks that extra edge.
author: Brian J.

description:
This place is great, pizza is great, toppings are great, people are great. 
I used to come here all the time for work, and still get delivery or a slice when Im drunk. 

Why 3 stars? Because of one particular bitch working behind the counter. Now I'll admit it was Halloween, so its busy as hell right?

We call to place an order togo, it ends up being 45 min, so we call back 15 minutes later to request it be delivered, ok. They call back and tell us to pick it up in 20 minutes. I wait 30, go there. Wait in line , again not a problem because its busy I understand, I work in retail. I ask the lady about the order, she tells me oh it'll be 5 minutes in in the oven. I see what appears to be my pizza go into the oven. Now... I give her the benefit of the doubt, and then 5 minutes later ask her because Im in a rush, can I have whats just coming out of the oven on the slices to go. Told her I can mix whatever just give me a full pizza to go. She gives me a shitload of attitude and tells me its in the oven so wait. Then some other guy goes and asks another person to do the same thing, and it works. So I request it again 15 minutes later and the guy says 5 more minutes, and later decides to give me another pizza in the oven. 

Seriously bottom line, I would've given this place a 5, but because you're not willing to work with your cusotmers a bit, you get a 3. 

I'm sorry to 95 % of the staff, but the girl who had the slit neck costume working on halloween was a bitch.
author: Steven C.

description: Yum yum . Ooey, gooey toopings plus crispy crust . YUM YUM !
author: Jenny Y.

description:
Like Green Eggs and Ham I love this pizza.  So tasty
    I do like them in a box.
    I do like them with a fox.
    I do like them in a house.
    I do like them with a mouse.
    I do like them here or there.
    I do  like them anywhere.
    I do like green This Pizza.
    I do like them, Jen-I-am.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
YUM-O!
like jessica d. states its great @ 2 a.m. and that is exactly when i had it after a night out while i was in sf.  the place is always busy, and it did remind me of gynormous slices in nyc. tasted great and i will go back if i am ever fancying pizza when i head to sf anytime soon.
author: Tracy L.

description: Pretty good pizza for a chain. Really deserves 3.5 stars but I'm a stingy jerk so I rounded down. I save my fours for "special" places. Whatever that means.
author: Randy C.

description:
Inconsistent pizza: some issues to work on:

First thing:  crust should Never ever be white.  
The dough isn't consistent, and the crust is often too pale/doughy and not browned.  They have decent sauce, but they don't always put enough on.
author: purple z.

description:
Not my favorite Escape in the city, but their pizza here lives up to the standard very nicely. This is my preferred Escape for delivery and the pizza always comes fast, hot, and delicious. 

I also enjoy going out and grabbing a slice when I'm in the neighborhood. Their slice prices are pretty reasonable, but I'm used to the discount slice prices that the Escape in the Financial District gives. The seating at the location is pretty rough. The indoor seating sits about 5 people crammed into the bar at the window and the out door seating is a bunch of cheap patio chairs laid out on the street. Once while eating outside I reached to grab my ringing phone from my pocket and the cheap ass chair tipped over and threw me onto the curve. 

But I digress, the 4 star rating is maintained mostly by the extremely delicious pizza. The staff is somewhat robotic. They even have a cute robot girl working the counter weekday afternoons, but none of that changes the fact that the pizza here is amazing. Thin crispy crust with delicious luscious toppings. This is pizza the Escape Way, the Right Way.
author: Robert P.

description: What does it mean that this Escape from New York Pizza is a collaborative effort with Za's?
author: Wakako U.

description: I actually haven't tried the pizza from here, but I had the garden salad and it was surprisingly delicious salad for a pizza by the slice type place. There were artichokes, peppers, mushrooms, olives, tomatoes, etc...I was very pleased. The house vinaigrette dressing rocked, too. It was reasonably priced, I plan on coming back.
author: Anne A.

description:
I love this place. I moved here from Chicago the home of the best Pizza in the world and have finally found a pizza that is perfect.

Thin crust, huge slices, great toppings, fast delivery, and not too much cheese. I love it.
author: Abra A.

description: Pretty good slice.  I love NY style thin crust.  Its especially tough to find in SF where places make pizza too fancy...   I just want aregular slice...this place has a few posh pizzas but cant go wrong with cheese or combo!
author: Naji E.

description:
3 1/2 stars (rounded down)

I've never seen potato on a pizza before, but i like it!! took a break from the club next door and came here to grab something to eat.  our friends got a combo slice each, my girl got a potato and garlic slice, and I got the mushroom.  Don't remember how much it came out to, but it was worth it.  my girl's slice was good, except I don't like garlic.  She likes it, but with the size of the chunks they put on the pizza....one slice could kill a few hundred vampires!  Good thing she took them off before giving me a bite.  My slice was pretty good too.  
I don't know if pizza is made better in SF or if it's just the fact that I'm always really drunk when I'm having pizza in SF, but either way...it works out for me!
Reason I rounded down is because I thought I overheard one of the employees mumble something about us......you work at a pizza place that serves mostly drunk people from the club next door bro......keep any dumb ass comments you have about how drunk we are or anything like that to yourself until we leave.....
author: Ocee D.

description: Decent pizza and great location.  I was really missing pizza on Polk. It's a necessity.  Definitely took care of my pizza fix.  I'll have to try some other slices out.....better than what was been in that spot in the past.
author: Kirsten M.

description: This where Bambi usually camps out for a bite after hitting the bars in the Castro. Their sundry tomato and feta pizza is divine. Open late and never really busy... comes in handy after a few Mandarin soda's...to tame the belly.
author: Teddy d.

description:
this is a review for a fresh ordered pie and not the slices that have been sittin out ...chillin forevers.  

so loverboy has been telling me about how tasteee the potatoe pesto one is and last nite we got to experience the goodness togethers.  we did half potato pesto and half ham, mushroom and jalepenos. i was impressed with both sides. it was muy delish-i-oso. (be warned through.  on the potatoe pesto - there are roasted garlic cloves on it!!)  phew.  but you know the saying about garlic - just as long as you both have had it,  then ya'll will cancel each other out when kissing, rite?!    we got home and it was piping hot and delicious.  we shared it with a bottle of our chardonnay which complimented it perfectly.  yaay to pizza nites with vino!
author: Caroline S.

description:
I noticed that those giving this place rave reviews and judging by their names, probably have no idea if a pizza is good or not, or what the consistency of a pizza slice should be. For example, one guy gave his expert opinion by saying, "I want to be able to pick it up and not fall apart." That's a joke, right? You should want the mozzarella to be pulled like string taffy and the sauce to be thick with whole bits of tomato running through it. The crust should be crunchy without the feeling of biting into rock candy. No, the pizza shouldn't be soggy but it should bend in a few gazillion directions from the sheer weight of the cheese, sauce, and toppings. Besides, how the hell would you know that pizza was "never meant to be eaten with a knife and fork? When it comes out hot from the oven you can't possibly pick up a slice with your fingers, without getting second degree burns.
You think this place is good? REALLY? 
If you think this is good pizza then you don't know the difference between a pizza and a freight train.
I was visiting my son in San Francisco and was told throughout my lifetime that the food in "Frisco" was great! On July 4th, we were watching the fireworks and figured a couple of pizzas and a few beers would be the perfect combo, so we ordered a couple of pies for delivery. One pie was ordered with extra cheese. I could have said, "Hold the cheese" and would probably have gotten the same amount. The crust was dry and the taste was worse. I mean, how the hell do you screw up the crust? Even the bottom crust was as course and dry as sand. There wasn't enough beer available to moisten this crust. The sauce was, for lack of a better description, bitter and actually was unlike anything that should be described as pizza sauce. Once, at a party, I had the unfortunate experience of eating a pizza from a pizza chain.  I don't remember if it was Pizza Hut, Domino's, or whatever, but it was one hellava lot better than this red tinted manhole cover. 
I am of Italian descent, born in Brooklyn, and am not trying to be over critical but there is absolutely nothing positive that I can say about this pizza. You'd be better off with D'Giornio's.
author: Sal D.

description: Not really sure if this pizza is worth 4 stars or not, but I tend to wake up Saturday morning with a to-go box next to my bed and 2 greasy paper plates....which tends to remind me of my late night stop to Escape From New York the night before. Good, solid drunk food. Yes.
author: Kristen D.

description:
Good if it's fresh at 2 am, but at 2 in the afternoon it looks a little dried-out and forlorn.  

I had been hankering for a pizza by the slice place in the 'hood anyway.  Good if you are tired from work and just want to eat salty cheese on bread.  And it's thin, none of that doughy crap they call pizza on the West Coast.
author: jessica d.

description: Craving pizza and seeing it right in the area I was in I said heck with it...although I have been here before and not eaten, I decided to go this time and grub! I order my all time classic favorite pepperoni and sausage....I was not impressed. I like sausge that almost look like meatballs, not ground up spam! The sauce was not even tangy like real marinara and the pepperoni might as well as been salami. For the price Escape From New York Fell OFF!  I give it the Chuck Norris Thumb Down......
author: Jay G.

description: Mmmm, damn good HUGONGOUS slices. Very NY in the sense that you're getting thin crust with an array of toppings and you gotta fold it. To do anything less would be sacrilege.
author: Andrew K.

description: Sorry Nicky's but Escape from New York just does it better. The slice is only $3 and they manage to crisp the crust perfectly...
author: Nicolas H.

description: Being a New Yorker who knows her pizza, finding a decent pizza place once I moved to SF was a challenging and exhausting task. Lucky for me, I stumbled across this place and have been pleasantly surprised. While it's not REAL New York pizza, it's certainly better than 99% of the crap they call pizza in this town. Also, their salads are fan-frickin-tastic - yum, yum!!
author: Sadia J.

description: I am here nearly every day for lunch. If you don't have the time and need something quick, cheap, and delicious and you're in Russian Hill..go here! I think the guys who work there are amazing and always ever so friendly. The pizza they make always look so greasy and magical..so good, I'm there almost, if not every, day. And they play really good music. Everyone is always greeted with a warm smile and "hello!"
author: Dorothea G.

description: We come here from work at least once a week for a slice. Always the same crew working the counters, and always fresh pies coming out of the oven. One slice will do, and you'll still be productive when you get back to work. It's pretty much a staple.
author: Tom G.

description:
i just wrote a long review for nick's crispy tacos, which is next door to escape from new york.  i had to give nick's just three stars although i hope to return and give them more stars.  you see, i couldn't afford a whole meal at nick's because they are cash.only.  thus after sharing three standard tacos at nick's, my wife and i made our way into escape from new york to buy one slice of new york style pizza on credit card.  i'm just not a cash.carrying kind of guy because i like to track my expenses on mint.com.

actually, i waited in the car, while my wife ran in to fetch this slice of potato, garlic, pesto pizza.  you see, our parking meter had just expired, and i didn' t want to get a parking ticket.  i hate parking tickets and traffic tickets.  i need to go to traffic school this spring for a speeding ticket on homebound commute from tahoe.  we snowboard a lot, and that's a weekly commute.  now, i drive speed limit.

anyway, wow, even though i had to eat this slice while driving over to the embarcadero to look for wild parrots, i really enjoyed it.  this was great pizza.  we were in manhattan last september and had great new york pizza.  if you ask me, this was up on par with those ut had fancier toppings.  good stuff!

well, maybe someday, i'll return to get more of the full experience of escape form new york.  however, i give them thumbs up for now.  four stars.  i'd give more, but i save five stars for like fancy places that are also really good, etc.
author: beno h.

description: I am so happy you have finally made it to my neighborhood! hooray! Pesto pizza pesto pizza (and other tasty types but I always sway back to the pesto for some reason). This made me super duper happy and made a deliciouso Easter lunch!
author: Veronica G.

description: i stumbled upon this place after a night of drinking and dancing at the Rouge night club.  i had the roasted garlic and sliced potato pizza and it was unforgettable!  simply phenomenal!  being that i don't live in the area, i so wish it was more easily accessible for me, but i'm considering paying another visit soon!
author: Mala H.

description: So happy that Nick's pizza is gone and Escape has found a new happy home.  It's a joint venture with the folks from Za, so it's good, thin crust New York style pie without the agonizing 2 block walk up hill.
author: George K.

description:
Slow and gooey!

They said the pizza would arrive in 45 minutes or less, it arrived 60 minutes from the order time.  

The pizza was moderately hot when it arrived, but the dough was undercooked and gooey.   

There are too many better places to bother getting pizza from here again.
author: James B.

description:
This place gives out good coupons for those of us in Russian Hill / Pac Heights.  Buy one slice, get one free.

It's not exactly New York pizza, but it's pretty good.
author: P R.

description: So, as I was eating the piece of pesto pizza, I thought it was fantastic. Afterwards, not so much!  The crust was not cooked all the way and all three of us got really sick about 10 minutes after eating a couple slices.  In fact, my buddy was so ill, that a random girl was hitting on him and he couldn't even think about it, it was not awe-inspiring, to say the least.  Definitely made me wanna escape from escape from new york pizza, seriously....
author: Craig E.

description: Thank God the awful pizza place that was previously here is gone now.  This place is awesome for a fast, quick bite. They have delicious crust here.   I love the U Say Potato.  Yummy.
author: Squirrel L.

description: They have this really yummy potato pesto pizza.  Usually I've gone late at night after hitting up the bars on polk.  this place is perfect for the late night buzzed hunger.    I personally don't like really thick crust doughy pizza so this one is perfect because it has a good amount of topping and isn't too thick.   great location to just drop in for a snack but just don't expect to sit anywhere unless you're going at an off time.   it's a small space with just a few seats inside/outside.
author: T M.

description:
Pizza is just average but will suffice if you ever have a pizza attack.

There is very limited seating so it is basically a call and pick up to take home kind of place.
author: John C.

description:
worst service- they say they close at 11pm but if you are not there by 1030pm expect attitude and no service.

terrible.
author: steven s.

description: The taste of the crust varies in edibility, but to get a $3 sun dried tomato/artichoke heart/roasted garlic/basil slice of pizza, I can't complain too much. The fluorescent-lit ambiance makes doing take-out a good call.
author: Shannon R.

description: 2 stars just because they sell slices which is harder than you think to find in this city. Nothing fancy about the za, no avocado or seared ahi tuna as toppings, making it the only restaurant in san francisco not to offer those two foods.  Just good, solid new york style pizza.
author: Michael N.

description: This place has the best flippin' pizza I've ever tasted! Then again anything you eat when you're drunk is the best thing you've ever tasted. The crust was light and crunchy and the pizza was your typical pepperoni. 'Twas good drunk food. The only beef I have w/ them is that I think they took advantage of my handicapped state and overcharged me for my two slices. And 25 cents for ranch? C'mon!
author: Queenie C.

description: all i can say is that I was drunk with a lot hennesy....and when i found this place and bit into a slice was equal to the first experience of halo with friends.
